term.description: Addition
Subtraction
Multiplication
Division
Check if a is smaller than b
Check if a is greater than b
Check if a is smaller than or equal to b
Check if a is greater than or equal to b
Check if a is equal to b
Check that a is *not* equal to b
logical NOT. Returns `true` if a is empty. Note that for the purposes of logical operators, `0`, `''` and `false` are considered empty.

term.name: and
term.description: Check that both a and b are not empty. Note that for the purposes of logical operators, `0`, `''` and `false` are considered empty.

term.name: or
term.description: Check that at least a or b are not empty. Note that for the purposes of logical operators, `0`, `''` and `false` are considered empty.

term.name: where
term.description:
Filter a based on b. Both a and b should be lists.
For example, `event where type = 'conference'` will return only events whose type is "conference".
Same as [filter(a, b)](#filter), except smarter about scoping. For example, let's say in addition to events with types you also had attendees with types. With `filter()` you would need to write `filter(event, event.type = 'conference')` to get the same result as  `event where type = 'conference'`, because in `filter()`, `type` would be interpreted independently of `event` and would give you both event and attendee types in one big list. However, since `filter()` is more low-level, it can be useful for cases when you want to override the heuristics of `where`.

term.name: by
term.description: Same as [groupby(a, b)](#groupby).
Join two pieces of text, e.g. 'cat' & 's' becomes 'cats'

term.name: in
term.description: Same as [`has(a, b)`](#has).
Create a list with numbers from a to b. Same as [`range(a, b)`](#range)

term.name: if
term.description:
Get a different value based on a test. For example, `if(rating > 3, 'good', 'bad')` returns `'good'` if the rating is bigger than 3 and `'bad'` otherwise.
Any parameters can also be lists of values, in which case the `if()` is applied on each element individually (i.e. first the first element of each list, then the second, then the third etc).

argument.name: test
argument.description: The condition to test for.

argument.name: iftrue
argument.description: What to return if the test passes. Defaults to the test itself.

argument.name: iffalse
argument.description: What to return if the test doesnâ€™t pass. Defaults to "" (empty text).

term.name: list
term.description:
Creates a list of values, just like the kind of thing you get when you use collection properties (or properties inside them).

For those familiar with JS or JSON, something like `list(1, "Lea", 3)` is analogous to `[1, "Lea", 3]`.

argument.name: value1
argument.description: First value

argument.name: value2
argument.description: Second value
You can provide as many as you want

term.returnDescription: A list with all values you provided.

term.name: group
term.description:
Creates data that mimics the kind of data produced by a group.

For those familiar with JS or JSON, something like `group(name: 'Lea', age: 33)` is analogous to `{"name": "Lea", "age": 33}`)

argument.name: key1: value1
argument.description: First key-value pair or other group data.

argument.name: key2: value2
argument.description: Second key-value pair or other group data.
You can provide as many as you want

term.name: get
term.description:
Get a value of a group by key. For example, `get(group(bar:4), bar)` will return `4`.
If the first parameter is a collection, all values of the given key are returned. For example, `get(list(group(id:"foo", name:"fooname"), group(id:"bar", name:"barname")), name)` returns `list("fooname", "barname")`.
If the first parameter is a collection and the second parameter is in the form `"key=value"`, then the group(s) that satisfies this condition will be returned as a list. For example, `get(list(group(id:"foo", name:"fooname"), group(id:"bar", name:"barname")), "name=fooname")` returns `list(group(id:"foo", name:"fooname"))`.
You can attach a **key** to the end of `get()` with a `.` operator to get the value of a key. For example, `get(list(group(id:"foo", name:"fooname"), group(id:"bar", name:"barname")), "id=foo").name` returns `"fooname"`.

argument.name: object
argument.description: Where to look up keys and find values.

argument.name: key
argument.description: The key to look for or the condition to match if in the form `"key=value"`.

term.returnDescription: Value of found key or a list of values if multiple keys are found. Returns a list of groups if the second parameter is "key=value".

term.name: average
term.description: Calculate the average of all numbers in the list.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The numbers to average

term.name: median
term.description: Calculate the median of all numbers in the list. New in v0.2.0.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The numbers to average

term.name: sum
term.description: Sum all numbers in the list.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The numbers to sum

term.name: min
term.description:
Calculate the minimum of all numbers in the list.
`min()` also accepts multiple parameters of `Number` and returns the minimum number of all parameters. For example, `min(1, 2, 3)` will return `1`.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The numbers you are trying to find the min of.

term.name: max
term.description:
Calculate the maximum of all numbers in the list.
`max()` also accepts multiple parameters of `Number` and returns the maximum number of all parameters. For example, `max(1, 2, 3)` will return `3`.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The numbers you are trying to find the max of.

term.name: round
term.description: Rounds a number to the nearest integer. If the `decimals` parameter is used, rounds a number to the nearest number of decimals.

argument.name: number
argument.description: Number to be rounded.

argument.name: decimals
argument.description: Number of decimals the number will be rounded to.

term.name: digits
term.description:
Returns a number with the specified number of digits and decimal places.
For example, `digits(2, 1234.5678)` will return `34.5678`, a number with 2 digits and the number of decimals unchanged. `digits(2, 3, 1234.5678)` will return `34.567`, a number with 2 digits and 3 decimals.
If `digits` or `decimals` parameter is larger than the number of digits or decimals the number has, the number will be padded with 0s. For example, `digits(4, 5, 12.345)` will return `0012.34500`.

argument.name: digits
argument.description: Number of digits to keep. If `number` has fewer digits than the `digits` parameter, 0s will be padded before the number.

argument.name: decimals
argument.description: Number of decimal places to keep. If `number` has fewer decimals than the `decimals` parameter, 0s will be padded after the number's decimals.

argument.name: number
argument.description: Number to be changed.

term.returnDescription: New number with specified number of digits and decimal places.

term.name: count
term.description: Count how many items in a list actually have a value. Ignores 0, false, "", empty.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The list of values to count.

term.name: first
term.description: Get the first item(s) in a list of values.

argument.name: n
argument.description: How many items to return? Defaults to 1.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The list to return items from.

term.returnDescription: If n is not provided or is 1, the first item. Otherwise, a list of the first n items.

term.name: last
term.description:
Get the last item(s) in a list of values. 
For example, assuming there is a collection with the name `event`, `last(event)` gets you the last event and `last(3, event)` gets you the last 3 events.

argument.name: n
argument.description: How many items to return? Defaults to 1.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The list to return items from.

term.returnDescription: If n is not provided or is 1, the last item. Otherwise, a list of the last n items.

term.name: unique
term.description:
Drops any duplicates, returning only the unique items from a list of values.
For example, `unique(list(1, 2, 1, 4, 4, 3, 2))` will return `list(1, 2, 3, 4)`.

term.name: shuffle
term.description: Shuffle the list, i.e. randomize the order of items.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The list to shuffle.

term.returnDescription: A new, shuffled version of the list provided.

term.name: intersects
term.description:
Checks if two lists share one or more of the same item.
For example, `intersects(list(1, 2, 3), list(4, 3, 5))` will be true because both share the item `3`.
term.returnDescription: True if there is an intersection and false if not.

term.name: reverse
term.description: Reverse the order of list items.
term.returnDescription: A list with its item orders reversed.

term.name: filter
term.description:
Filter a based on b. Both a and b should be multi-valued. Similar to the [`where` operator](#where) but with none of its scoping "magic".
For example, `filter(event, event.type = 'conference')` will return only events whose type is "conference". Note how with the `where` operator we can just say `event where type = 'conference'` whereas with the `filter()` function we need to be more explicit about where `type` comes from. This can be useful in case Mavo predicts the wrong scope for `where`.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The list to filter

argument.name: filter1
argument.description: The list whose values to use as filters

argument.name: filter2
argument.description: Optional extra filter(s)
Optional extra filter(s)

term.returnDescription: A list with the same number of items as list and empty values in the positions where at least one filter had a falsy value or the original values where all filters had truthy values.

term.name: condense
term.description:
Get rid of empty values in a list.
For example, assuming we have a list of events whose type is "conference": `event where type = 'conference'`. This list has the same number of items as the source list of events and might have empty values corresponding to events with types other than "conference". `condense(event where type = 'conference')` will return a list of conferences without empty values. In other words, `count(condense(event where type = 'conference')) <= count(event where type = 'conference')`.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The list to drop empty values from

term.returnDescription: A list without empty values in it

term.name: groupby
term.description:
**Experimental, introduced in v0.2.0**
Groups a list of values based on another list. The intermediate structure returned can be either rendered by itself (with the help of `mv-value`) or fed into aggregate functions ([`count()`](#count), [`average()`](#average), [`median()`](#median), [`min()`](#min), [`max()`](#max)). For those who are familiar with SQL, the use cases this addresses are very similar to those addressed by SQL's `GROUP BY`.
Can also be written more succinctly as `values by key`.

For example, let's assume you have a list of people with names and ages. `groupby(name, round(age / 10) * 10)` or `name by round(age / 10) * 10` will return a list of groups of names by decade of age. You can also name the key with `as`:  `groupby(name, round(age / 10) * 10) as decade` or `name by round(age / 10) * 10 as decade`
You can feed that into `count()` to get a count of how many people belong to each decade: `count(name by round(age / 10) * 10)`.

argument.name: values
argument.description: Values to create the groups from

argument.name: key
argument.description: Values to group by

term.name: join
term.description: Combine multiple values into one text value, optionally separated by a different text value.

argument.name: list
argument.description: The pieces you want to join

argument.name: glue
argument.description: What to put between the joined pieces of text. Defaults to nothing, i.e. the pieces are just concatenated. Provide `', '` to get a comma-separated list.

term.name: split
term.description: The opposite of `join()`, this takes a text value and turns it into a list, by breaking it down at the specified separators.

argument.name: text
argument.description: The text to split.

argument.name: separator
argument.description: Where to split the text. Defaults to whitespace.

term.name: between
term.description: Finds two pieces of text and returns the text between them.

argument.name: haystack
argument.description: Text to look in.

argument.name: from
argument.description: Text after this will be returned

argument.name: to
argument.description: Text before this will be returned

argument.name: tight
argument.description: If true, the function will search "from" parameter from the end of the haystack and "to" parameter from the start of haystack. Useful when there are multiple occurrences of from or to and you want the shorter in-between text.

term.returnDescription: Text in between from and to

term.name: from
term.description: Returns all texts after another bit of text.

argument.name: haystack
argument.description: Text to look in.

argument.name: needle
argument.description: Text to look for.

term.name: fromlast
term.description: Same as `from()` but searches for the needle starting with the **last** character of the haystack instead of the first.

argument.name: haystack
argument.description: Text to look in.

argument.name: needle
argument.description: Text to look for.

term.name: to
term.description: Returns all texts before another bit of text.

argument.name: haystack
argument.description: Text to look in.

argument.name: needle
argument.description: Text to look for.

term.name: tolast
term.description: Same as `to()` but searches for the needle starting with the **first** character of the haystack instead of the last.

argument.name: haystack
argument.description: Text to look in.

argument.name: needle
argument.description: Text to look for.

term.name: random
term.description: Generate a random number.

argument.name: min
argument.description: Minimum allowed number. Defaults to 0.

argument.name: max
argument.description: Maximum allowed number. Defaults to 100.

argument.name: step
argument.description: Step, i.e. allowed increment. Defaults to 1, which returns integers.

term.name: range
term.description:
Create a list with numbers starting from a and increasing one by one until b. E.g. `range(5)`, `range(1, 5)`, and range(1, 5, 1) all produce `list(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)`. If only a and b are needed, `range(a, b)` can also be written more succinctly as [`a .. b`](#..).

Useful both in `mv-value`, to repeat something a specific number of times, or in conjunction with multi-valued functions, to calculate something over a series of numbers.

argument.name: a
argument.description: The first number in the sequence. Defaults to 1 or -1 depending on whether b is positive or negative respectively.

argument.name: b
argument.description: The upper bound for the sequence. Please note that if `a` is not an integer, the last number in the sequence may not be equal to `b`. E.g. `range(.5, 2)` returns `list(0.5, 1.5)`.

argument.name: step
argument.description: The difference between consecutive numbers in the sequence. Defaults to 1 or -1 depending on the relative order of a and b. If the provided step would result in an infinite sequence, the result is a list with a as its only element. E.g. `range(1, 5, 0)` or `range(1, 3, -1)` both would return `list(1)`.

term.returnDescription: The resulting sequence of numbers as a list

term.name: year
term.description: Get the year of a date/time as a 4 digit number.

argument.name: date
argument.description: The date/time whose year we want to get.

term.name: month
term.description:
Get the month of a date/time as a number from 1 to 12. You can add `'name'` as the second parameter to get the month name (e.g. "February"). You can also use `'shortname'` to get a shorter name, like "Feb". Both of these are dependent on the document language.
If you want to display the month as a two digit number, add `'00'` as the second parameter. For example, `month(2019-02-01, '00')` returns `02`.

argument.name: date
argument.description: The date/time whose month we want to get.

argument.name: format
argument.description: The way we want this month to be displayed.

term.name: weekday
term.description: Get the weekday of a date/time as a number from 1 to 7. You can add `'name'` as the second parameter to get the weekday name (e.g. "Monday"). You can also use `'shortname'` to get a shorter name, like "Mon". Both of these are dependent on the document language.

argument.name: date
argument.description: The date/time whose weekday we want to get.

argument.name: format
argument.description: The way we want this weekday to be displayed.

term.name: day
term.description: Get the weekday of a date/time as a number from 1 to 31.

argument.name: date
argument.description: The date/time whose day we want to get.

term.name: hour
term.description: Get the hour of a date/time as a number from 0 to 23.

argument.name: date
argument.description: The date/time whose hour we want to get.

term.name: minute
term.description: Get the minute of a date/time as a number from 0 to 59.

argument.name: date
argument.description: The date/time whose minute we want to get.

term.name: second
term.description: Get the seconds of a date/time as a number from 0 to 59.

argument.name: date
argument.description: The date/time whose seconds we want to get.

term.name: date
term.description: Get a date (without time) in ISO format (e.g. 1986-13-06).

argument.name: date
argument.description: The date/time that we want to format

term.name: time
term.description: Get the time part of a date/time (without date information) in ISO format (e.g. 13:00).

argument.name: date
argument.description: The date/time that we want to format

argument.name: precision
argument.description: Precision for the returned timestamp. "hours" returns times like "14:00" (ignores minutes), "minutes" returns times like "14:27", "seconds" returns times like "14:27:05", "ms" returns times like "14:27:05.345". Default is "seconds". Any unknown value is ignored.

term.name: seconds
term.description: Converts a number of milliseconds to a number of seconds. Essentially equivalent to dividing by 1000 and then rounding down.

argument.name: ms
argument.description: Number of milliseconds

term.name: minutes
term.description: Converts a number of milliseconds to a number of minutes. Essentially equivalent to dividing by 60 Ã—1000 and then rounding down.

argument.name: ms
argument.description: Number of milliseconds

term.name: hours
term.description: Converts a number of milliseconds to a number of hours. Essentially equivalent to dividing by 60 Ã— 60 Ã—1000 and then rounding down.

argument.name: ms
argument.description: Number of milliseconds

term.name: days
term.description: Converts a number of milliseconds to a number of days. Essentially equivalent to dividing by 24 Ã— 60 Ã— 60 Ã—1000 and then rounding down.

argument.name: ms
argument.description: Number of milliseconds

term.name: weeks
term.description: Converts a number of milliseconds to a number of weeks. Essentially equivalent to dividing by 7 Ã— 24 Ã— 60 Ã— 60 Ã—1000 and then rounding down.

argument.name: ms
argument.description: Number of milliseconds

term.name: months
term.description: Converts a number of milliseconds to a number of months. Essentially equivalent to dividing by 30.4368 Ã— 24 Ã— 60 Ã— 60 Ã—1000 and then rounding down.

argument.name: ms
argument.description: Number of milliseconds

term.name: years
term.description: Converts a number of milliseconds to a number of years. Essentially equivalent to dividing by 12 Ã— 30.4368 Ã— 24 Ã— 60 Ã— 60 Ã—1000 and then rounding down.

argument.name: ms
argument.description: Number of milliseconds

term.name: duration
term.description:
Displays time intervals using a count of seconds, minutes, hours, days, months, or years, based on what would produce the most readable result. Supports localization. For more granular results, you can supply a number of terms, or even a specific unit.
To display the interval between two days in human readable text, you just subtract the two dates for the `ms` argument.

Examples:
- `duration(10000)` will print out "10 seconds"
- `duration(100000000)` will print out "1 day".
- `duration(100000000, 2)` will print out "1 day, 3 hours"
- `duration(100000000, 'hours')` will print out "27 hours"
- `duration($now - end_date)` will display the time that has passed between `end_date` and now

argument.name: ms
argument.description: Number of milliseconds

argument.name: unit
argument.description: Number of max terms or specific unit (e.g. 'days'). If omitted, only 1 term (the most suitable) will be used.

term.name: len
term.description: Find the length in characters of a text value. E.g. len("foo") is 3.

argument.name: text
argument.description: The text to measure

term.name: idify
term.description: Convert text to something that looks like the ids we are more used to. For example, `idify("Chicken Liver PÃ¢tÃ©! ðŸ˜‹")` returns `"chicken-liver-pate"`

argument.name: text
argument.description: The text to convert

term.name: ordinal
term.description: Returns the ordinal indicator (st, nd, rd, th) of a given number.

argument.name: number
argument.description: Number used to determine the ordinal character.

term.returnDescription: The ordinal indicator corresponding to the number.

term.name: readable
term.description:
The opposite of `idify()`, this takes an id (either in camelCase, or in underscore_case, in hyphen-case, or even mixed) and tries its best to convert it to a readable label. For example, `readable("fooBar-baz")` returns `"Foo bar baz"`.
Also used by Mavo internally to generate the editing UI from property names.

argument.name: id
argument.description: The id-like text to convert.

term.name: uppercase
term.description: Converts all letters to uppercase.

argument.name: text
argument.description: The text to convert.

term.name: lowercase
term.description: Converts all letters to lowercase.

argument.name: text
argument.description: The text to convert.

term.name: replace
term.description: Replaces all occurrences of a text with another text.

argument.name: haystack
argument.description: Text to look in.

argument.name: needle
argument.description: Text to look for.

argument.name: replacement
argument.description: Text that replaces needle.

argument.name: iterations
argument.description: Number of times search and replace is performed. Defaults to 1

term.name: search
term.description: Case-insensitive search

argument.name: haystack
argument.description: Text to look in

argument.name: needle
argument.description: Text to look for

term.returnDescription: Position of the first match if found, or -1 if not found.

term.name: phrase
term.description: Provides access to Mavo's localization system, for language-sensitive text. You can define your own phrases as described [here](https://mavo.io/docs/ui#localization)

argument.name: id
argument.description: The id of the phrase to use.

argument.name: vars
argument.description: If the phrase is parameterized, this includes values for the sub-phrases.

argument.name: lang
argument.description: Optional language code. If omitted, uses the Mavo app's language.

term.name: contains
term.description:
Check if a collection, group, list, or text contains another given text. For example, `contains("Kenneth", "Ken")` returns `true`.
If both haystack and needle are a list, `contains()` checks if the first item of the haystack contains the first item of the needle, and so on, and returns a list of corresponding results. For example, `contains(list("Kenneth", "Verou"), list("Ken", "Lea"))` will return `list(true, false)`.

argument.name: haystack
argument.description: Where to look in.

argument.name: needle
argument.description: What to look for.

term.returnDescription: True if the haystack contains the needle, false otherwise.

term.name: has
term.description:
Search for `needle` in one or more haystacks. If using multiple haystacks, the result is equivalent to `has(needle, haystack) and has(needle, haystack2) and has(needle, haystack3) and ...`.
`has(needle, haystack)` can also be written more succinctly as [`needle in haystack`](#in).

The search is performed in the following way:
- If `haystack` is a list, `needle` is compared against each value, and if it matches any of them, `true` is returned. This is the most common case. E.g. `has("Lea", list("David", "Lea", "Chris"))` returns `true`.
- If `haystack` is a group, `true` is returned if `needle` matches the name of any property in the group. This is analogous to JavaScript's `in` operator. E.g. `has("Lea", group(Lea: 33, David: 50))` returns `true`.
- If `haystack` is a simple value (text, number etc), `has()` is equivalent to an equality comparison (`needle = haystack`). E.g. `has(1, 1)` returns `true` and `has(1, 2)` returns `false`.

argument.name: needle
argument.description: What to search for

argument.name: haystack
argument.description: List or group to search in

argument.name: haystack2
argument.description: Additional list or group to search in
Additional list(s) or group(s) to search in

term.returnType: True or False or list of True/False values
term.returnDescription: true if the search is successful, false otherwise. If needle is a list, the result will also be a list

term.name: starts
term.description: Check if text starts with another bit of text

argument.name: haystack
argument.description: Text to look in

argument.name: needle
argument.description: Text to look for

term.returnDescription: True if it does, false otherwise.

term.name: ends
term.description: Check if text ends with another bit of text

argument.name: haystack
argument.description: Text to look in

argument.name: needle
argument.description: Text to look for

term.returnDescription: True if it does, false otherwise.

term.name: url
term.description:
If `param` is provided, returns the value of that parameter from the current page URL. This matches both parameters like `example.com/index.html?foo=bar` and `example.com/index.html/foo/bar` with the former having priority over the latter
If `param` is **not** provided, it returns the URL of the current page.

argument.name: param
argument.description: The parameter to get.

term.name: filename
term.description:
Gets all texts after the rightmost slash of an URL. For example, `filename("https://mavo.io/docs/functions.html")` will return `functions.html`.
If the parameter is not an URL, `filename()` will return the value of the parameter as-is.
term.returnDescription: Text after the rightmost slash of an URL. Returns the value of the parameter as-is if not an URL.

term.name: json
term.description: Converts data to JSON.

argument.name: data
argument.description: Data to be converted to JSON.

term.name: log
term.description:
Logs the result of all parameters to the browser console and returns the result of the first parameter of this function.
For example, `log(1 + 1, floor(3.5), true && false)` will return `2`, the result of the first parameter of `log()`. Additionally, when you open the browser console, `2 3 false` will be displayed.
This function is primarily for **advanced** Mavo users and developers. To debug your Mavo app, the [Mavo Inspector](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/mavo-inspector/fcjdobllamgdbbjhhhpghnffideklgpa) Chrome extension may be more useful (works only with the development version of Mavo).

argument.name: parameter1
argument.description: The first parameter to be logged to the browser console.

argument.name: parameter2
argument.description: The second parameter to be logged to the browser console.
You can provide as many as you want.

term.returnDescription: The result of the first parameter.

term.name: $now
term.description: Current date and time as number of milliseconds since January 1st, 1970. Note that using `$now` in expressions makes them update automatically as `$now` changes. Mostly useful in conjunction with [date and time functions](?category=datetime) or the `mod` operator.

term.name: $startup
term.description: The value of `$now` when the page loaded.

term.name: $today
term.description: Current date.

term.name: $hash
term.description: Current URL hash (without the `#` sign). Updates automatically when the hash changes.

term.name: $mouse
term.description: Mouse coordinates relative to the viewport. Use `$mouse.x` and `$mouse.y` to get them.

term.name: $index
term.description: If inside a collection, the closest itemâ€™s position in its collection, starting from 0.

term.name: $previous
term.description: If inside a collection, the closest itemâ€™s previous item.

term.name: $next
term.description: If inside a collection, the closest itemâ€™s next item.

term.name: $item
term.description: If inside a collection, the closest item. Same as using the property name.

term.name: $all
term.description: If inside a collection, the collection (since the collection property will give you the current item)

term.name: $this
term.description: The closest group. Particularly useful in conjunction with [`where`](#where). E.g. `person where age > $this.age` from inside a person item to count how many people are older
